To assure quality, automated testing in a simple and inexpensive system enables complete characterization of throughput and fiber metrology. Future applications include larger IFUs, higher fill factors with stripped buffer, de-cladding, and lenslet coupling.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6081">     <title>The activation of Woollins' reagent. Isolation of pyridine stabilised PhPSe2</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6081</link>     <description>Abstract: Woollins' reagent (WR, (PhPSe2)2) plays an essential role in the selenation of organic compounds. Reaction of WR with pyridine gives the P(V) species PhPSe2 stabilised by pyridine coordination which is the first crystallographically characterised mononuclear RPSe2 system stabilised by an external molecule and has potential as a selenation reagent for reactions under mild conditions. Description: Date of Acceptance: 22/04/2014</description>     <dc:date>2014-06-14T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Ascherl, Laura</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Nordheider, Andreas</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Athukorala Arachchige, Kasun Sankalpa</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Cordes, David Bradford</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Karaghiosoff, Konstantin</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Buehl, Michael</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Slawin, Alexandra Martha Zoya</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Woollins, J Derek</dc:creator>     <dc:description>Woollins' reagent (WR, (PhPSe2)2) plays an essential role in the selenation of organic compounds. Reaction of WR with pyridine gives the P(V) species PhPSe2 stabilised by pyridine coordination which is the first crystallographically characterised mononuclear RPSe2 system stabilised by an external molecule and has potential as a selenation reagent for reactions under mild conditions.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6080">     <title>Reversible control of nanoparticle functionalization and physicochemical properties by dynamic covalent exchange</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6080</link>     <description>Abstract: Existing methods for the covalent functionalization of nanoparticles rely on kinetically controlled reactions, and largely lack the sophistication of the preeminent oligonucleotide-based noncovalent strategies. Here we report the application of dynamic covalent chemistry for the reversible modification of nanoparticle (NP) surface functionality, combining the benefits of non-biomolecular covalent chemistry with the favorable features of equilibrium processes. A homogeneous monolayer of nanoparticle-bound hydrazones can undergo quantitative dynamic covalent exchange. The pseudomolecular nature of the NP system allows for the in situ characterization of surface-bound species, and real-time tracking of the exchange reactions. Furthermore, dynamic covalent exchange offers a simple approach for reversibly switching\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdand subtly tuning\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdNP properties such as solvophilicity. Description: This work was supported by the EPSRC (EP/K016342/1 and DTG), the University of St Andrews, and by a Royal Society of Edinburgh/Scottish Government Fellowship (E.R.K.).</description>     <dc:date>2015-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>della Sala, Flavio</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Kay, Euan Robert</dc:creator>     <dc:description>Existing methods for the covalent functionalization of nanoparticles rely on kinetically controlled reactions, and largely lack the sophistication of the preeminent oligonucleotide-based noncovalent strategies. Here we report the application of dynamic covalent chemistry for the reversible modification of nanoparticle (NP) surface functionality, combining the benefits of non-biomolecular covalent chemistry with the favorable features of equilibrium processes. A homogeneous monolayer of nanoparticle-bound hydrazones can undergo quantitative dynamic covalent exchange. The pseudomolecular nature of the NP system allows for the in situ characterization of surface-bound species, and real-time tracking of the exchange reactions. Furthermore, dynamic covalent exchange offers a simple approach for reversibly switching\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdand subtly tuning\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdNP properties such as solvophilicity.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6079">     <title>Review Essay: Homelessness, Liberation Theology and Faith Based Organisations</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6079</link>     <dc:date>2014-12-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Doherty, Joe</dc:creator>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6078">     <title>Advancing energy justice : the triumvirate of tenets and systems thinking</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6078</link>     <dc:date>2013-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>McCauley, Darren</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Heffron, Raphael</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Stephan, Hannes</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Jenkins, Kirsten Elizabeth Harrison</dc:creator>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6077">     <title>The pervasive role of biological cohesion in bedform development</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6077</link>     <description>Abstract: Sediment fluxes in aquatic environments are crucially dependent on bedform dynamics. However, sediment-flux predictions rely almost completely on clean-sand studies, despite most environments being composed of mixtures of non-cohesive sands, physically cohesive muds and biologically cohesive extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) generated by microorganisms. EPS associated with surficial biofilms are known to stabilize sediment and increase erosion thresholds. Here we present experimental data showing that the pervasive distribution of low levels of EPS throughout the sediment, rather than the high surficial levels of EPS in biofilms, is the key control on bedform dynamics. The development time for bedforms increases by up to two orders of magnitude for extremely small quantities of pervasively distributed EPS. This effect is far stronger than for physical cohesion, because EPS inhibit sand grains from moving independently. The results highlight that present bedform predictors are overly simplistic, and the associated sediment transport processes require re-assessment for the influence of EPS. Description: Date of Acceptance: 09/01/2015</description>     <dc:date>2015-02-06T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Malarkey, Jonathan</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Baas, Jaco</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Hope, Julie Anne</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Aspden, Rebecca Jane</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Parsons, Daniel R.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Peakall, Jeff</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Paterson, David Maxwell</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Schindler, Robert</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Ye, Leiping</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Lichtman, Ian D.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Bass, Sarah J.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Davies, Alan G.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Manning, Andrews J.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Thorne, Peter D.</dc:creator>     <dc:description>Sediment fluxes in aquatic environments are crucially dependent on bedform dynamics. However, sediment-flux predictions rely almost completely on clean-sand studies, despite most environments being composed of mixtures of non-cohesive sands, physically cohesive muds and biologically cohesive extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) generated by microorganisms. EPS associated with surficial biofilms are known to stabilize sediment and increase erosion thresholds. Here we present experimental data showing that the pervasive distribution of low levels of EPS throughout the sediment, rather than the high surficial levels of EPS in biofilms, is the key control on bedform dynamics. The development time for bedforms increases by up to two orders of magnitude for extremely small quantities of pervasively distributed EPS. This effect is far stronger than for physical cohesion, because EPS inhibit sand grains from moving independently. The results highlight that present bedform predictors are overly simplistic, and the associated sediment transport processes require re-assessment for the influence of EPS.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6076">     <title>Socially learned habituation to human observers in wild chimpanzees</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6076</link>     <description>Abstract: Abstract Habituation to human observers is an essential tool in animal behaviour research. Habituation occurs when repeated and inconsequential exposure to a human observer gradually reduces an animal\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds natural aversive response. Despite the importance of habituation, little is known about the psychological mechanisms facilitating it in wild ani- mals. Although animal learning theory offers some account, the patterns are more complex in natural than in laboratory settings, especially in large social groups in which individual experiences vary and individuals influ- ence each other. Here, we investigate the role of social learning during the habituation process of a wild chim- panzee group, the Waibira community of Budongo Forest, Uganda. Through post hoc hypothesis testing, we found that the immigration of two well-habituated, young females from the neighbouring Sonso community had a significant effect on the behaviour of non-habituated Waibira indi- viduals towards human observers, suggesting that habitu- ation is partially acquired via social learning. Description: Fieldwork of CH and LS was funded by grants from the British Academy and a Leverhulme Trust\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Research Leadership Award.</description>     <dc:date>2014-02-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Samuni, Liran</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Mundry, Roger</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Terkel, Joseph</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Zuberbuehler, Klaus</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Hobaiter, Cat</dc:creator>     <dc:description>Abstract Habituation to human observers is an essential tool in animal behaviour research. Habituation occurs when repeated and inconsequential exposure to a human observer gradually reduces an animal\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds natural aversive response. Despite the importance of habituation, little is known about the psychological mechanisms facilitating it in wild ani- mals. Although animal learning theory offers some account, the patterns are more complex in natural than in laboratory settings, especially in large social groups in which individual experiences vary and individuals influ- ence each other. Here, we investigate the role of social learning during the habituation process of a wild chim- panzee group, the Waibira community of Budongo Forest, Uganda. Through post hoc hypothesis testing, we found that the immigration of two well-habituated, young females from the neighbouring Sonso community had a significant effect on the behaviour of non-habituated Waibira indi- viduals towards human observers, suggesting that habitu- ation is partially acquired via social learning.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6075">     <title>City of details : interpreting the personality of London</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6075</link>     <description>Abstract: This article investigates the ways in which a group of enthusiasts for London constitute their city. The 'personality' attributed to London is described, as well as the interpretive acts that reveal it. These people, who also lead walking tours across the city, privilege 'detail' as their term of analysis. The article examines the identified qualities of that category, in particular its perceived capacity to animate the plural time-spaces of the city. This sensitivity to detail is presented as part of a sensing of place, which allows people to regard themselves as uniquely able to see the city. The article is intended as a contribution to the ethnography of London.</description>     <dc:date>2002-03-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Reed, Adam Douglas Evelyn</dc:creator>     <dc:description>This article investigates the ways in which a group of enthusiasts for London constitute their city. The 'personality' attributed to London is described, as well as the interpretive acts that reveal it. These people, who also lead walking tours across the city, privilege 'detail' as their term of analysis. The article examines the identified qualities of that category, in particular its perceived capacity to animate the plural time-spaces of the city. This sensitivity to detail is presented as part of a sensing of place, which allows people to regard themselves as uniquely able to see the city. The article is intended as a contribution to the ethnography of London.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6074">     <title>The use of genome wide association methods to investigate pathogenicity, population structure and serovar in Haemophilus parasuis</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6074</link>     <description>Abstract: Haemophilus parasuis is the etiologic agent of Glasser's disease in pigs and causes devastating losses to the farming industry. Whilst some hyper-virulent isolates have been described, the relationship between genetics and disease outcome has been only partially established. In particular, there is weak correlation between serovar and disease phenotype. We sequenced the genomes of 212 isolates of H. parasuis and have used this to describe the pan-genome and to correlate this with clinical and carrier status, as well as with serotype. Description: This work was supported by a BPEX PhD studentship and a Longer and Larger (LoLa) grant from the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council (grant numbers BB/G020744/1, BB/G019177/1, BB/G019274/1 and BB/G003203/1), the UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs and Zoetis, awarded to the Bacterial Respiratory Diseases of Pigs-1 Technology (BRaDP1T) consortium. Date of Acceptance: 12/12/2014</description>     <dc:date>2014-12-24T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Howell, Kate J</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Weinert, Lucy A</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Chaudhuri, Roy R</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Luan, Shi-Lu</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Peters, Sarah E</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Corander, Jukka</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Harris, David</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Angen, \ufffd\ufffdystein</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Aragon, Virginia</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Bensaid, Albert</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Williamson, Susanna M</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Parkhill, Julian</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Langford, Paul R</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Rycroft, Andrew N</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Wren, Brendan W</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Holden, Matthew T</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Tucker, Alexander W</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Maskell, Duncan J</dc:creator>     <dc:description>Haemophilus parasuis is the etiologic agent of Glasser's disease in pigs and causes devastating losses to the farming industry. Whilst some hyper-virulent isolates have been described, the relationship between genetics and disease outcome has been only partially established. In particular, there is weak correlation between serovar and disease phenotype. We sequenced the genomes of 212 isolates of H. parasuis and have used this to describe the pan-genome and to correlate this with clinical and carrier status, as well as with serotype.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6073">     <title>Isothiourea-mediated asymmetric functionalization of 3-alkenoic acids</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6073</link>     <description>Abstract: Isothiourea HBTM-2.1 promotes the catalytic asymmetric alpha-functionalization of 3-alkenoic acids through formal [2 + 2] cycloadditions with N-tosyl aldimines and formal [4 + 2] cycloadditions with either 4-aryltrifluoromethyl enones or N-aryl-N-aroyl diazenes, providing useful synthetic building blocks in good yield and with excellent enantiocontrol (up to >99% ee). Stereodefined products are amenable to further synthetic elaboration through manipulation of the olefinic functionality. Description: This work is supported by funding from the Carnegie Trust for the Universities of Scotland (L.C.M.) and the European Research Council under the European Union\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Seventh Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013)/ERC Grant Agreement No. 279850.</description>     <dc:date>2014-02-21T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Morrill, Louis C.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Smith, Samuel M.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Slawin, Alexandra M. Z.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Smith, Andrew D.</dc:creator>     <dc:description>Isothiourea HBTM-2.1 promotes the catalytic asymmetric alpha-functionalization of 3-alkenoic acids through formal [2 + 2] cycloadditions with N-tosyl aldimines and formal [4 + 2] cycloadditions with either 4-aryltrifluoromethyl enones or N-aryl-N-aroyl diazenes, providing useful synthetic building blocks in good yield and with excellent enantiocontrol (up to >99% ee). Stereodefined products are amenable to further synthetic elaboration through manipulation of the olefinic functionality.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6072">     <title>Isothiourea-catalyzed asymmetric synthesis of \ufffd\ufffd-lactams and \ufffd\ufffd-amino esters from arylacetic acid derivatives and N-sulfonylaldimines</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6072</link>     <description>Abstract: The isothiourea HBTM-2.1 (5 mol %) catalyzes the asymmetric formal [2 + 2] cycloaddition of both arylacetic acids (following activation with tosyl chloride) and preformed 2-arylacetic anhydrides with N-sulfonylaldimines, generating stereodefined 2,3-diaryl-\ufffd\ufffd-amino esters (after ring-opening) and 3,4-diaryl-anti-\ufffd\ufffd-lactams, respectively, with high diastereocontrol (up to >95:5 dr) and good to excellent enantiocontrol. Deprotection of the N-tosyl substituent within the \ufffd\ufffd-lactam framework was possible without racemization by treatment with SmI2. Description: This work is supported by a Royal Society for a University Research Fellowship and the EPSRC and GSK (Case Award) as well as by the European Research Council under the European Union\ufffd\ufffds Seventh Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013) (ERC Grant Agreement No.279850)</description>     <dc:date>2014-02-21T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Smith, Siobhan R.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Douglas, James</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Prevet, Hugues</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Shapland, Peter</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Slawin, Alexandra M. Z.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Smith, Andrew D.</dc:creator>     <dc:description>The isothiourea HBTM-2.1 (5 mol %) catalyzes the asymmetric formal [2 + 2] cycloaddition of both arylacetic acids (following activation with tosyl chloride) and preformed 2-arylacetic anhydrides with N-sulfonylaldimines, generating stereodefined 2,3-diaryl-\ufffd\ufffd-amino esters (after ring-opening) and 3,4-diaryl-anti-\ufffd\ufffd-lactams, respectively, with high diastereocontrol (up to >95:5 dr) and good to excellent enantiocontrol. Deprotection of the N-tosyl substituent within the \ufffd\ufffd-lactam framework was possible without racemization by treatment with SmI2.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6071">     <title>Evaluating unsupervised fault detection in self-healing systems using stochastic primitives</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6071</link>     <description>Abstract: Autonomous fault detection represents one approach for reducing operational costs in large-scale computing environments. However, little empirical evidence exists regarding the implementation or comparison of such methodologies, or offers proof that such approaches reduce costs. This paper compares the effectiveness of several types of stochastic primitives using unsupervised learning to heuristically determine the root causes of faults. The results suggest that self-healing systems frameworks leveraging these techniques can reliably and autonomously determine the source of an anomaly within as little as five minutes. This finding lays the foundation for determining the potential these approaches have for reducing operational costs and ultimately concludes with new avenues for exploring anomaly prediction. Description: This research was partially supported by the Scottish Informatics and Computer Science Alliance (SICSA). Date of Acceptance: 09/01/2015</description>     <dc:date>2015-01-28T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Schneider, Christopher</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Barker, Adam David</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Dobson, Simon Andrew</dc:creator>     <dc:description>Autonomous fault detection represents one approach for reducing operational costs in large-scale computing environments. However, little empirical evidence exists regarding the implementation or comparison of such methodologies, or offers proof that such approaches reduce costs. This paper compares the effectiveness of several types of stochastic primitives using unsupervised learning to heuristically determine the root causes of faults. The results suggest that self-healing systems frameworks leveraging these techniques can reliably and autonomously determine the source of an anomaly within as little as five minutes. This finding lays the foundation for determining the potential these approaches have for reducing operational costs and ultimately concludes with new avenues for exploring anomaly prediction.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6070">     <title>Simulated biogas for nickel-based solid oxide fuel cells</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6070</link>     <description>Abstract: Biogas is composed of variable gases including hydrogen, nitrogen and sulphur, with methane and carbon dioxide as the main components. The common ratio of methane to carbon dioxide is 60/40 in volume and this high amount of methane causes carbon deposition when biogas is used in solid oxide fuel cells. To prevent carbon deposition, dry reforming, steam reforming or partial oxidation is the common method. In this paper, a nickel cermet solid oxide fuel cell was investigated with a simulated biogas based on 63% CH4 and 37% CO2, which was obtained by presuming 80% fuel utilisation and 25% recirculation of anode gas. Supplied with a 30 ml/min of simulated biogas, the cell generated a maximum power density of 856 mW cm-2 at 850 \ufffd\ufffdC. The cell ran stably at loads of 100 mA cm-2, 300 mA cm-2and 500 mA cm-2 over a period of 16 hours at each level.</description>     <dc:date>2014-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Ma, J.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Jiang, C.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Cassidy, M.</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Irvine, J.T.S.</dc:creator>     <dc:description>Biogas is composed of variable gases including hydrogen, nitrogen and sulphur, with methane and carbon dioxide as the main components. The common ratio of methane to carbon dioxide is 60/40 in volume and this high amount of methane causes carbon deposition when biogas is used in solid oxide fuel cells. To prevent carbon deposition, dry reforming, steam reforming or partial oxidation is the common method. In this paper, a nickel cermet solid oxide fuel cell was investigated with a simulated biogas based on 63% CH4 and 37% CO2, which was obtained by presuming 80% fuel utilisation and 25% recirculation of anode gas. Supplied with a 30 ml/min of simulated biogas, the cell generated a maximum power density of 856 mW cm-2 at 850 \ufffd\ufffdC. The cell ran stably at loads of 100 mA cm-2, 300 mA cm-2and 500 mA cm-2 over a period of 16 hours at each level.</dc:description>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6069">     <title>Identification of a fluorometabolite from Streptomyces sp. MA37 : (2R3S4S)-5-fluoro-2,3,4-trihydroxypentanoic acid</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/10023/6069</link>     <description>Abstract: (2R3S4S)-5-Fluoro-2,3,4-trihydroxypentanoic acid (5-FHPA) has been discovered as a new fluorometabolite in the soil bacterium Streptomyces sp. MA37. Exogenous addition of 5-fluoro-5-deoxy-D-ribose (5-FDR) into the cell free extract of MA37 demonstrated that 5-FDR was an intermediate to a range of unidentified fluorometabolites, distinct from fluoroacetate (FAc) and 4-fluorothreonine (4-FT). Bioinformatics analysis allowed identification of a gene cluster (fdr), encoding a pathway to the biosynthesis of 5-FHPA. Over-expression and in vitro assay of FdrC indicated that FdrC is a NAD+ dependent dehydrogenase responsible for oxidation of 5-FDR into 5-fluoro-5-deoxy-lactone, followed by hydrolysis to 5-FHPA. The identity of 5-FHPA in the fermentation broth was confirmed by synthesis of a reference compound and then co-correlation by 19F-NMR and GC-MS analysis. The occurrence of 5-FHPA proves the existence of a new fluorometabolite pathway. Description: DOH thanks EPSRC and the ERC for financial support. He also acknowledges the Royal Society for a Wolfson Merit Award. KK and HD thank the Leverhulme Trust; Royal Society Africa Award (AA090088). Date of Acceptance: 26/11/2014</description>     <dc:date>2015-02-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:creator>Ma, Long</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Bartholome, Axel Jacques Guy</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Tong, Ming Him</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Qin, Zhiwei</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Yu, Yi</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Shepherd, Thomas</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Kyeremeh, Kwaku</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>Deng, Hai</dc:creator>     <dc:creator>O'Hagan, David</dc:creator>     <dc:description>(2R3S4S)-5-Fluoro-2,3,4-trihydroxypentanoic acid (5-FHPA) has been discovered as a new fluorometabolite in the soil bacterium Streptomyces sp. MA37. Exogenous addition of 5-fluoro-5-deoxy-D-ribose (5-FDR) into the cell free extract of MA37 demonstrated that 5-FDR was an intermediate to a range of unidentified fluorometabolites, distinct from fluoroacetate (FAc) and 4-fluorothreonine (4-FT). Bioinformatics analysis allowed identification of a gene cluster (fdr), encoding a pathway to the biosynthesis of 5-FHPA. Over-expression and in vitro assay of FdrC indicated that FdrC is a NAD+ dependent dehydrogenase responsible for oxidation of 5-FDR into 5-fluoro-5-deoxy-lactone, followed by hydrolysis to 5-FHPA. The identity of 5-FHPA in the fermentation broth was confirmed by synthesis of a reference compound and then co-correlation by 19F-NMR and GC-MS analysis. The occurrence of 5-FHPA proves the existence of a new fluorometabolite pathway.</dc:description>   </item> </rdf:RDF>
